The project would also assist in the implementation of road sector reforms. Specifically, the project is comprised of: Component A (US$61.5 m): Pilot Road Rehabilitation Program to rehabilitate about 400 km of international, primary and secondary roads distributed among the four regions of the country. Component B (US$4.8 m): Technical assistance to: (i) support a Program Impiementation Unit; (ii) carry out a detailed Road User Charges Study; (iii) assist in the implementation of the Statement of Road Sector Policy; and (iv) strengthen the Directorate of Roads in the implementation of the Road Rehabilitation Program. Component C (US$1.5 m): Equipment, including laboratory equipment, traffic counting and axle load control equipment. Benefits: Detailed evaluation of the national road network, and selection of road sections to be rehabilitated, has been carried out utilizing the World Bank's Highway Design and Maintenance Standards Model (HDM-III). The results of these studies indicate that the rehabilitation works proposed to be implemented under the RRP have very high economic rates of return. The Modified IRR estimated for the program shows an overall rate of return of 30 percent. Additional benefits include: establishment of self-financing mechanisms for the road sector through the introduction of user charges, employment generation among poorer segments of society through geographically dispersed road works, and enhancement of road safety. Risks: Implementation risks for the proposed project, as well as for the overall Road Rehabilitation Program, relate to: (a) the present weaknesses in the implementation capacity of Directorate of Roads (DOR); and (b) the need to secure significant financial resources for the rehabilitation program. With regard to the former, the project design seeks to mitigate the institutional capacity risk through creation of a Program Implementation Unit (PIU) within the Ministry of Public Works (MPW) with adequate powers in the areas of planning, resource allocation, procurement and monitoring of works implementation. In relation to the financing risk, the major uncertainty is a delay in implementation of the road user charges which could jeopardize financing of the RRP. These financing risks are mitigated by the Government's commitment to full cost recovery in the road sector as set out in the Statement of Road Sector Policy.

INTRODUCTION 1.1 The prolonged 17-year conflict in Lebanon and the consequent neglect of the road network has resulted in a considerable backlog of maintenance, and about 35 percent of the overall network is now in poor condition. Failure to address this problem in a timely manner will lead to large economic losses both due to high vehicle operating costs as well as due to losses of the physical infrastructure which would then require expertsive reconstruction. It is estimated that reducing "poor condition" roads to about 10 percent of the network, which is about the average for well-managed road networks, would produce savings for the Lebanese economy of about US$100.0 million/year on account of vehicle operating cost savings alone. Preservation of the network would generate additional savings by avoiding costly reconstruction in the future. Urgent action is needed to restore the network and preserve existing road assets. The Government of Lebanon (GOL) is therefore initiating a major Road Rehabilitation Program (RRP) to rehabilitate about 3,500 km of roads. The proposed National Roads Project (NRP), which is to support this overall program by financing institutional strengthening and a pilot program of road rehabilitation works, is consequently a high priority for the Government in the transport sector. II. THE ROAD SECTOR 2.1 Roads are critical to the efficient functioning of the Lebanese economy, being the only mode of internal transport, and the main transportation link with the regional hinterland which is, and will continue to be, a major factor in the country's development. Furthermore, expenditures on roads is one of the single largest components of the Government's budget (second only to civil service salaries), and hence efficiency in the road sector also has significant fiscal implications for the country. This section gives an overview of the road sector and highlights some of the key issues. A more detailed discussion of the sector is provided in the project files (Project Working Papers). A. The Road Network 2.2 Lebanon's road network is extensive and well distributed throughout the country (0.63 km/sq. km). Excluding municipal roads, it comprises about 6,330 km subdivided into four categories: international roads (530 km), primary roads (1,650 kin), secondary roads (1,340 km), and local roads (2,810 km). More than 80 percent of this network, including all primary roads, consists of two-lane bituminous roads which are usually narrow and winding with structures varying in width, load capacity and condition. A detailed inventory made during 1995 of the first three categories revealed that 36 percent of the national network (excluding local roads) is in poor condition, as shown in Table 1 below.

High traffic densities are also found along the coastal highway to the south, and on the highway from Beirut to the Bekaa valley. The motor vehicle fleet has been increasing rapidly; even during the war years the fleet grew from about 265,000 vehicles in 1974 to 670,000 vehicles in 1986. Recent estimates indicate a fleet of about I million vehicles, which for a population of about 4 million indicates a high vehicle ownership ratio (1 vehicle/4 persons). Rapid expansion of the automobile fleet is partly attributable to the virtual collapse of public transport systems in the country as a consequence of the civil war. The Bank is assisting the Government, under a Japan - PHRD Grant funded technical assistance, in formulating a program to address public transport issues and facilitate private investment in the delivery of urban transport services. 2.4 In addition to the high traffic volumes, parts of the Lebanese road network are also subjected to high tr;ffic loads due to the heavy vehicle traffic generated by the reconstruction works now underway. The results of axle load surveys indicate a significant axle load problem, primarily caused by the transport of construction materials and the lack of enforcement of axle load controls. Trucks causing the greatest damage are the 2-axic heavy trucks and the 3-axle rigid trucks, which are the most popular truck types in the fleet. For 2-axle heavy trucks, 35 percent of the trucks registered single axle loads of 14 to 24 tons, while for 3-axle rigid trucks 50 percent registered axle loads of 14 to 22 tons. The legal limit on a single axle is 14 tons, but the regulations now in place are complex and difficult to enforce. The potential benefits of enforcement are, however, very significant. It is estimated that improving regulations and enforcement to international standards would result in a reduction in road pavement damage on the order of between 27 and 44 percent. The proposed project, therefore, proviees for the installation of weigh-bridges at selected locations to allow implementation of an enhanced system of axle load controls. B. Institutional Framework 2.5 The Directorate of Roads (DOR) within the Directorate General of Highways and Buildings (DGHB) of the Ministry of Public Works (MPW) is responsible for road maintenance. The organizational structure of DOR within the MPW is shown in Chart 1. Over the war years, institutional capacity for administration of the road network was severely depleted. This loss of institutional capacity
 3 is best illustrated by the reductions in skilled manpower that DOR has suffered: in late 1994, out of 10 established positions at the Grade II level, 9 were vacant, and at the Grade III level, out of 115 positions, 81 were vacant. Overall, DOR now has about 70 percent of its approximately 500 authorized positions vacant. Any program for rehabilitation of the road network would therefore also have to address the need to create adequate institutional structures and capabilities. In addition to DOR, the Council for Development and Reconstruction (CDR), and the Conseil Executif des Grands Projets (CEGP) also undertake road works but they mainly undertake larger projects implemented through private contractors and are not responsible for maintenance. C. Pnb!ic Expenditures in the Road Sector 2.6 Funding for the road sector is provided under three government budgets: the MPW budget, the CDR budget, and the CEGP budget. The latter two are for new construction and major works implemented as large projects. Maintenance funding is provided through the MPW budget and is implemented by DOR either through contracted works or, to a much lesser extent, through force account operations using DOR's own labor, plant and equipment. Presently, MPW's road maintenance budget is around US$60 million per year. About 90 percent of the budget is expended through contracted works, and there exists a sizeable local road construction industry with 37 private contractors capable of undertaking road works valued at up to US$10 million per contract. 2.7 In order to assess the adequacy of maintenance expenditures, a comparison was made with other countries on the basis of average maintenance expenditures per kilometer of network. Since the comparator countries have higher standard road networks, it could be expected that their expenditure levels (per kilometer) would be higher than in Lebanon. On the contrary, however, expenditures for the Lebanese network are about twice those of the highest cost comparator - Finland. Maintenance of the Finnish network is tspecially problematic due to climatic factors and the existence of a large lumber industry which regnlarly moves large numbers of heavy vehicles over the network. The extremely high cost of maintaining the Lebanese network may be explained by two factors, first, the poor condition of the network, which requires excessive expenditures to provide a reasonable riding surface, and second, inefficiencies duc to a lack of systematic planning and control of expenditures. D. The Road Rehabilitation Program 2.8 Recognizing the urgency to carry out a systematic evaluation of rehabilitation needs for the road network, the CDR engaged consultants in December 1994 to develop a comprehensive Road Rehabilitation Program using the Highways Design and Maintenance Standards Model (HDM) and its supporting Expenditure Budgeting Model (EBM), which have been developed by the World Bank. The study was in twc phases. Phase I involved data collection and economic analysis to define the priority program, and Phase II to prepare detailed designs for the first year program. Data was collected describing the current roadway characteristics and traffic, the expected traffic growth, the vehicle fleet characteristics and unit costs, the unit costs of road maintenance operations, and the characteristics of the maintenance strategies to be evaluated. The analysis is discussed in greater detail in Section V - Economic Evaluation. Based on this evaluation an overall road rehabilitation program was defined and a detailed description is in the project files (Project Working Papers). E. Road Sector PerCormance 2.9 Present problems in the road sector are evident from the following observations: 36 percent of the Lebanese road network is in poor condition, as compared with 12 percent on average for well managed networks and 22 percent on average for poorly managed networks', and is resulting in economic losses of about US$140 million/year. Annual expenditures for maintenance of the Lebanese network at about US$10,(00/km is more than twice the level for stable, well maintained networks (US$2,000 to US$5,000/km), but these high expenditures have not resulted in a significant improvement in the overall network condition. High axle loads cause excessive damage to roads, and large numbers of trucks are found to have axle loads in the 18-22 ton range as compared with a normal design limit of 13 tons - doubling axle loads increases pavement damage by a factor of 16 (4th power). Bad road conditions (lack of guard rails, signage, etc.) cause many accidents. For July, 1995 the figures were 88 fatalities, which is about 10-12 fatalities per 100 million vehicle-km compared with European Union rates of 2.7 per 100 million vehicle-km. To deal with the problems effectively, there is a need to strengthen institutional capacity in the road sector and this will require both strengthening the existing institution, i.e. DOR, as well as augmenting the institutional structure to create the accountability and separation of functions, implementation vs. budgeting and programming, necessary to prevent the inefficiency now evident in the sector. Weaknesses in the DOR cause expenditures on roads to not achieve commensurate results due to DOR's inability to resist various pressures to undertake works without adequate planning and justification. The ability of DOR to re-establish its institutional capacity is constrained by limitations in areas such as its ability to recruit trained personnel, to enter into contracts, and to mobilize necessary financial resources. These considerations have led the Government to decide, as an integral part of the RRP, on restructuring the institutional framework in the road sector. The reforms to be implemented are set out in a Statement of Road Sector Policy (Annex 1) and are sumimarized below. A. Statement of Road Sector Policy 3.2 Government recognizes the present institutional weaknesses in the sector, and also that they represent an opportunity to rebuild the institutional framework based on improved concepts of effective road sector administration and financing, and increased responsiveness to the needs of road users. At negotiations. a detailed Statement of Road Sector Policy was agreed. and this statement has been confirrned bv the Government as its policg for the sector. Key elements of this policy are: (a) to develop the national road network in ways that promote regionally and socially balanced development of the country; (b) to preserve the existing road network, which is a major infrastructure asset critical to the nation's economic well-being, in a cost-effective manner and to enhance its safety and efficiency; (c) to reduce the reliance of the road sector on the Government's recurrent bud,et and increase efficiency in road use over time by recovering from users the cost of providing roads; (d) to create a strong institutional capacity in the road sector capable of deploying modern planning, design and management technologies to achieve the objectives of this policy; and (e) to develop the capacity of the road sector to mobilize resources to finance the rehabilitation and improvement of the road network. The full te~xt oi the Statement of Road Sector Policy, as approved by the Council of Ministers on May 9, i996, is in Annex 1. B. Road User Charges 3.3 Success of the proposed reforms in the road sector, and in particular those elements related to the financing of the sector, requires that the level of user charges established be adequate to provide the financial resources needed for maintenance of the road network. An efficient structure of user charges is also essential to providing the right incentives for efficiency in the use of road assets. Important considerations in setting user charges would be to reduce the environmental impacts of excessive fuel use, and to recover from heavy vehicles the higher costs they impose through increased pavement damage. Surcharges on petrol/diesel, vehicle license fees and heavy vehicle fees would be the primary user charges utilized. As it will be difficult to introduce major changes in user charges at one time, a phased program of user charge increases is to be developed through a Road User Charges Study, with initial shortfalls
 6 in cash flows being covered by borrowings against future revenues. Such a program of user charge increases, would include appropriate corrections for inflation and productivity enhancements. It should be noted here that fuel prices in Lebanon are still somewhat below prices in neighboring countries (LebanoL US$0.35/ltr versus Syria US$0.41/ltr in December 1995). Since the level of road user charges would be based on assessments of the cost of maintaining the existing network, any network expansion or other extraordinary expenditures without compensating revenues (e.g., tolls on a new road) would require either additional increases in user charges or a specific budget transfer. Satisfactory completion of the Road User Charges study by September 30, 1997 is a covenant of the prorosed Loan. C. Full cost recovery from road users for rehabilitation and maintenance of the road network will be achieved over a period of three to five years between 1998 and 2003. Revenues from the above sources would be deposited in a Trust Account at the Banque du Liban called the Road Fund. THE PROJECT 4.1 The National Roads Project's objectives are to: (i) implement a pilot road rehabilitation program in support of the RRP; (ii) strengthen institutional capacity for maintenance and development of the national road network; and (iii) reduce reliance on the Government's budget by requiring users to pay for the provision of roads. 4.2 Rationale for Bank Involvement. The Bank's strategy in Lebanon is primarily driven by the country's extensive reconstruction needs which, after the long civil war and the consequent neglect of infrastructure development, calls for efficient utilization of very limited public resources for rebuilding the country's infrastructure. The proposed project is consistent with this overall country assistance strategy, which was discussed by the Board on June 30, 1994, and which, inter alia, supports rehabilitation of infrastructure and strengthening core functions of public administration. With a view to minimizing budgetary impacts, the project seeks to assist the Government in rehabilitating its road network with a significant portion of the needed financial resources being mobilized from road users, rather than funded from the general budget. More importantly, the project creates the institutional structures critical to future development of the road sector, and the Bank is in a unique position (given its experience across countries) to assist the Government in this difficult area. A. Project Description 4.3 The National Roads Project would help finance a three-year pilot program of urgently needed road rehabilitation works and the necessary technical assistance in support of the Government's Road Rehabilitation Program. The main components of the proposed project are: A. Road Rehabilitation Works. A three-year pilot program to rehabilitate about 400 km of selected international, primary and secondary roads distributed among the four Regional Directorates of Roads. B. Technical Assistance to: (i) support the MPW's Program Implementation Unit (PIU) in planning and programming works, preparing guidelines for and reviewing feasibility/environmental studies, undertaking all procurement actions necessary for the project, and monitoring outputs; (ii) carry out a detailed road user charges study to recommend the level and structure of tariffs; (iii) assist in the preparation of laws and regulations to implement the Statement of Road Sector Policy; and (iv) strengthen the capacity of the Directorate of Roads to develop and implement the Road Rehabilitation Program, including preparation of feasibility/environmental studies and supervision of works.
 8 C. Equipment. Procurement of vehicles, computers, office equipment, road laboratory equipment, traffic counting equipment and axle-load control equipment for better management of roads. A more detailed description of the project is presented in Annex 2. 4.4 The road rehabilitation works will be carried out in accordance with design standards established for the Road Rehabilitation Program (a detailed description of the program is in the Project Working Papers). All the works will be carried out on existing alignments, except for minor improvements to meet design standards and for traffic safety. Rehabilitation will consist mainly of pavement strengthening and drainage improvements. Road intersections will be corrected and "blackspots" will be eliminated to reduce road accidents, and on all project roads safety barriers, road signs, and road markings will be provided. To increase the level of service of the road network, the carriageway of the classified roads will be widened as rights of way permit, or when the required expropriation does not require resettlement, to achieve the minimum objective of 7 meter wide carriageway and 1.5 meter wide shoulders for international and primary roads, and 6 meter width and 1.5 meter shoulders for secondary roads. It is expected that this pilot program will be implemented in three successive groups of projects to be launched during the first three years of the RRP. Roads to be rehabilitated under the project in the first year have been selected and their details are provided in Annex 2. B. ECONOMIC EVALUATION 5.1 This section presents the economic evaluation of the overall RRP and of the individual road works components selected for the first-year pilot program to be financed under the proposed project. The economic evaluation is based on studies carried out by consultants engaged by CDR to develop a cost effective rehabilitation program. The studies utilized the HDM model and its associated EBM model, developed by the World Bank, to assess maintenance and rehabilitation strategies for the existing network and to optimize these strategies under budgetary constraints in order to determine the best possible allocation of funds. The HDM model simulates road deterioration and computes the road maintenance and vehicle operating cost streams for each of the strategies being evaluated, as well as the economic indicator used to compare these strategies, i.e., the net present value (NPV) of benefits to society. The EBM model is an optimization program used to select, under budget constraints, for each road a strategy that maximizes the net benefits to society of the group of roads being evaluated. Details of the analysis are presented in Annex 7, and the following provides a summary.

Road Network Characterization 5.2 Based on road inventory data and road condition and traffic surveys carried out, the network was divided into more than 300 uniform sections, with an average length of 9 km and uniform characteristics with respect to traffic, condition and road width. Road condition was assessed using the International Roughness Index (IRI). According to the results of the roughness survey, about 13.1 percent of the network surveyed is in Good condition (IRI < 4), 47.8 percent in Fair condition (4 < IRI < 6), 35.7 percent in Poor condition (6<IRI <9) and 3.3 percent in Critical condition (IRI>9). To evaluate the whole Lebanese network the road sections needed to be classified into homogenous "representative links" according to the following criteria: (a) four road condition levels - Good, Fair, Poor and Critical; (b) seven traffic volume ranges based on the Average Daily Traffic (ADT < 400, 400-1000, 1000-2000, 2000- 3000, 3000-5000, 5000-10000, and > 10000); and (c) four road width classes (one lane, narrow two lane, two lane, and four lane). In total, 112 (4x7x4) representative links were established from the combination of the variables described above. Traffic growth rates of 4 percent p.a. from 1995 to 2004 and 3 percent p.a. from 2005 to the end of the analysis period were assumed. B. Costs and Benefits 5.3 Both construction costs and vehicle operating costs were converted to economic costs by eliminating taxes, duties and subsidies. Distortions due to exchange rate variations were eliminated by expressing the unit vehicle operating costs in US dollar terms and by computing the project costs (construction and future maintenance) in US dollars (see Annex 7, Tables 7.2, 7.3 and 7.4). Vehicle Operating Costs 5.4 In order to establish the Vehicle Operating Costs (VOC) for the common vehicle types in Lebanon, a vehicle operating costs survey was carried out around the Greater Beirut area. The vehicle fleet was characterized by six vehicle types: cars, pickups, buses, medium trucks, heavy trucks and articulated trucks. For each vehicle type, financial costs of fuel, tires, new vehicle prices and labor costs were collected. In order to arrive at economic costs, shadow pricing techniques have been used to adjust financial costs and thus eliminate the effects of transfer payments (mainly taxes, import duties and subsidies). Annex 7, Table 7.2 shows the vehicle characteristics and economic unit costs used in the analysis. Annex 7, Table 7.3 shows typical unit vehicle operating costs at different levels of road roughness obtained using the Vehicle Operating Cost model of the HDM. Rehabilitation Strategies 5.5 A series of feasible periodic maintenance and rehabilitation operations (four overlay thicknesses and two reconstruction types) were identified and the corresponding unit costs and characteristics were defined. Annex 7, Table 7.4 shows the unit costs of maintenance operations used in the analysis. For links in fair to critical condition, an optimal rehabilitation operation, based on engineering principles, was adopted as the first periodic action and this action was assumed to take place either in the first year .1997) or postponed to the second through the eighth years. Also, for each link a different (lower standard) first periodic operation was evaluated taking place on the same years. In all cases, after the first periodic action is executed, it was assumed that it would be followed by condition-responsive overlays of 6 cm activated at roughness of 4.0 IRI.

Five-Year Budget Constraints 5.6 The rehabilitation strategy for the network was evaluated using the EBM model for a number of budget scenarios; the changes in NPV and average roughness of the network are shown in Annex 7, Figures 1 and 2. In all cases, the recurrent expenditures as well as the periodic expenditures after year 7 were left unconstrained. The no-budget constraint case presents the theoretically optimal solution, which is not practical because it produces an unequal distribution of the program. In this case, most of the expenditures take place in the first year followed with few expenditures in years 2 to 5. A uniform budget constraint of US$60 million/year represents a more practical solution that yields an expenditure program of about US$254 million in the first five years. Based on these assessments, the final rehabilitation program was developed using a set of budget constraints over five years, which took into consideration the build-up of iriplementation capacity and the objective of early completion of the rehabilitation program. Regionally and Socially Balanced Economic Development 2. Promotion of regional and social balance through expansion of the road network to areas needing improved access, through works programs which increase employment opportunities, or through contracting arrangements which encourage the growth of a diverse and dynamic road construction industry, are therefore considered worthwhile activities within this policy framework for the road sector.  Annex 7 Page I of 13 LEBANESE REPUBLIC NATIONAL ROADS PROJECT Maintenance & Rehabilitation of Lebanon Road Network Economic Analysis 1. During the past few years, the Ministry of Public Works (MPW) initiated several efforts to meet the minimum requirements for the maintenance of the classified network. However, there was an urgent need to define a cost effective program for the rehabilitation and strengthening of the classified road network and to develop an overall road maintenance strategy. Such a program would allow the present backlog of maintenance work to be progressively reduced over the coming few years, and would ensure that the funds available for maintenance works are allocated in the most cost effective manner. The Council for Development and Reconstruction (CDR) has developed such a program supported by a network economic evaluation based on the Highways Design and Maintenance Standards Model (HDM) and the supporting Expenditure Budgeting Model (EBM), which have been developed by the World Bank. This program is presented in the study: Identification, Preparation and Economic Evaluation of a Five- Year Road Rehabilitation Program, prepared by consultants engaged by CDR. A. Objectives 2. The objectives of the study are: (a) to define the optimal budget requirements for an overall road maintenance strategy for the rehabilitation and strengthening of the classified road network (excluding local roads); (b) prepare a five-year program based on this overall network economic evaluation, including a first year priority program; (c) to quantify the economic benefits of such a program and the expected improvements on the current level of service; and (d) to quantify the consequences of adopting sub-optimal strategies due to budget constraints. B. Methodology 3. The study was composed of two phases. Phase I involved the data collection process and economic analysis to define the priority program, and Phase II prepared detailed designs for the first year program. Data was collected describing the current roadway characteristics and traffic, the expected traffic growth, the vehicle fleet characteristics and unit costs, the road maintenance operations unit costs, and the characteristics of the maintenance strategies to be evaluated. The data collected for the road inventory included, among others, the horizontal and vertical alignment, cross sections, pavement type, and drainage characteristics. Network surveys included a traffic survey, a limited axle load survey, a roughness and visual pavement condition survey, and a vehicle operating costs survey. The network under study comprises 2,787.8 km of International, Primary and Secondary roads where data was available. Local roads and the remainder of the International, Primary and Secondary roads (mainly in the occupied parts of South Lebanon) were not included in this study. The former was excluded from the scope of the analysis, while the latter (about 100 km) were not covered due to difficulties of access and data collection in the buffer zone.
 Annex 7 Page 2 of 13 4. The HDM and EBM models have been used to assess maintenance and rehabilitation strategies for the existing network and to optimize the maintenance strategies under budgetary constraints in order to determine the best possible allocation of funds. The HDM model simulates road deterioration and computes the road agency and vehicle operating cost streams for each of the strategies being evaluated, as well as the economic indicator used to compare these strategies, i.e., the net present value (NPV) of benefits to society. The EBM model is an optimization program used to select, under budgetary constraints, for each road a strategy that maximizes the net benefits to society for the group of roads being evaluated. Road Network Characterization 5. Based on the inventory data and the condition and traffic surveys, the network under study was divided into more than 300 uniform sections with an average length of 9 km and uniform characteristics with respect to traffic, condition and road width. Road Condition was assessed using the International Roughness Index (IRI). According to the results of the roughness survey, about 13.1 percent of the network surveyed is in Good condition (IRI < 4), 47.8 percent in Fair condition (4 < IRI < 6), 35.7 percent in Poor condition (6 < IRI < 9) and 3.3 percent in Critical condition (IRI > 9). The findings of the traffic survey revealed that close to 61 percent of the estimated traffic is concentrated on about 320 kilometers of Intemational and Primary roads (about 13 percent of the network). 6. For the HDM model to be used to evaluate the whole Lebanese network, the road sections were classified into homogenous "representative links" by various engineering and traffic variables. The sections were grouped into representative links based on the following criteria: (a) four road condition levels - Good, Fair, Poor and Critical; (b) seven traffic volume ranges based on the Average Daily Traffic (<400, 400-1000, 1000-2000, 2000-3000, 3000-5000, 5000-10000, and > 10000); and (c) four road width classes (one lane, narrow two lane, two lane, and four lane). In total, 112 (4x7x4) representative links were established from the combination of the variables described above. Table 7.1 shows the analytical matrix that represents the road network surveyed. Vehicle Operating Costs 7. In order to establish the Vehicle Operating Costs (VOC) for the common vehicle types in Lebanon, a passenger and goods vehicle operating costs survey was carried out around the Greater Beirut area. From the surveys, it was found that the average age of passenger vehicles is 14 years, whereas for goods vehicles the average age is 18 years. For each vehicle type, financial costs of fuel, tires, new vehicles and labor were collected. In order to arrive at economic costs, shadow pricing techniques have been used to adjust financial costs and thus eliminate the effects of transfer payments, mainly taxes, import duties and subsidies. Table 7.2 shows the vehicle characteristics and economic unit costs used in the analysis. Table 7.3 shows typical unit vehicle operating costs at different levels of road roughness obtained using the HDM model. Maintenance Strategies 8. A series of feasible periodic maintenance and rehabilitation operations (four overlay thicknesses and two reconstruction types) were identified, and corresponding unit costs and characteristics were defined. Table 7.4 shows the unit costs of maintenance operations used in the analysis. For all links, a periodic maintenance action can be expected immediately or in the near future. Therefore, we are
 Annex 7 Page 3 of 13 interested in evaluating this first action as well the effects of postponing it. For links in fair to critical condition, an optimal rehabilitation operation, based on engineering principles, was adopted as the first periodic action and this action was assumed to take place in either the first year (1996) or postponed to the second to the eiglith year. Also, for each link, a different (lower standard) first periodic operation was evaluated taking place in the same years. In all cases, after the first periodic action is executed, it was assumed that it would be followed by condition-responsive overlays of 6 cm activated at roughness of 4.0 IRI. For links in good condition, the first maintenance action was assumed to take place between years four and eleven, followed by condition-responsive overlays of 6 cm at roughness of 4.0 IRI. Five-Year Budget Scenarios 9. The HDM model was run using the HDM Manager 3.0 for all representative links with an analysis period of 20 years, a discount rate of 12 percent and a traffic growth rate of 4 percent from 1995 to 2004 and 3 percent from 2005 upto the end of the analysis period. The optimal strategy for each link was found using the EBM model for the following budget scenarios: Scenario A: No budget constraints Scenario B: Periodic expenditures limited to US$60 mi/year Scenario C: Periodic expenditures limited to US$50 n/year Scenario D: Periodic expenditures limited to US$40 m/year Scenario E: Periodic expenditures limited to US$30 m/year Scenario F: Periodic expenditures limited to US$20 m/year Scenario G: Periodic expenditures limited to US$10 m/year Scenario H: Periodic expenditures limited to US$35, US$45, US$5, US$55 & US$50 m in years 1, 2, 3, 4 & 5 In all cases the recurrent expenditures were left unconstrained as well as the periodic expenditures after year seven. The no budget constraint case (scenario A) presents the theoretically optimal solution, which is not practical because it presents an unequal distribution of the program in the first five years. In this case, most of the periodic expenditures takes place in the first year followed with few expenditures in years two to five. This solution is not realistic but it is computed to give us the total periodic expenditures needed for the first five years, in this case is US$260.0 million. Scenario B presents uniform periodic expenditures of US$60.0 million/year, representing a more practical solution that yields about US$254.0 million in the first five years. Scenarios C to G present different budget constraint cases where the yearly uniform periodic expenditures are being reduced gradually. Finally, Scenario H presents the budget over the next five years based on an assessment of the maximum practical rehabilitation expenditures considering institutional capacity constraints. 10. Having determined the optimal practical budget scenario and obtained the corresponding five-year program, the next step was to determine the geographical distribution of the investments and compare the distributon with the proportion of the network in each Muhafazat. This has indicated that the distribution of expenditures are of the same magnitude as the proportion of the network in each Muhafazat. The distribution of investments was then adjusted slightly to take into account other non- economic factors. This regional analysis was then used as the basis for defining the actual work program, which also considered other programming requirements, such as practicality of contract packaging, bidding and execution.
 Annex 7 Page 4 of 13 C. Network Analysis Results 11. Table 7.5 shows the strategies selected by the HDM & EBM models for each representative link as a function of each budget scenario. Each strategy, other than the base strategy, is identified by a strategy code that is divided into two parts. The first two digits identify the first operation to be implemented and the last digits the timing of this first action (year). The possible operation codes are the following: (a) 00 for 4 cm overlay; (b) 01 for 6 cm overlay; (c) 02 for 8 cm overlay; (d) 03 for 10 cm overlay; (e) 04 for 12 cm overlay; (f) RI for reconstruction with 3.5 SN; and (g) R2 for reconstruction with a 5.0 SN. For example, for representative link "One lane / Poor / 0400" and for the proposed budget scenario the selected strategy is 02 6, that is a 8 cm overlay to take place in year 6 as the first periodic action followed by 8 cm overlays at roughness of 4 IRI. Following this coding system, we can identify, for each budget scenario, which links should be worked on each year and the operation needed. Having obtained the solution for each representative link, we also obtain the solution for each aniform road section that is a part of each representative link. These strategies were selected by the F3M model with the objective of maximizing the network net present value (NPV) of benefits to society under varying budget constraints or levels of implementation capacity. The resulting NPVs for each budget scenario, as well as the agency expenditures required to implement each scenario are also gi/en in Table 7.5. Economic Evaluation and Sensitivity Analysis 12. As can be expected, the economic returns of a rehabilitation/maintenance program are extremely high. For the overall rehabilitation program, the NPV for the selected expenditure program (Scenario H) is on the order of US$3,335 million for an expenditure of US$498.0 million (constant 1995 US$). The internmtl rates of return (IRR) calculated are consequently high (> 100%), and suffer from the implicit assumption that the benefits can be reinvested at the (high) rate of return of the investment, which is not likely in view of the high returns being generated. Therefore, the modified IRR has been calculated, which assumes that returns are reinvested at the opportunity cost of capital in the economy (around 12%), and this yields a much lower (modified) IRR. The modified IRR estimated for the Road Rehabilitation Program is 30 percent. Table 7.5 shows the results of changes in costs and benefits, and the high returns are not significantly affected by a 15 percent increase in costs and decrease in benefits, whose combined effect reduces overall NPV to US$2,772 million and the IRR to 28 percent. Projected Network Improvements 13. Figure I presents graphically the relationship between the rehabilitation programn's net benefits to society and the average annual periodic agency expenditures. We can see that scenarios A, B, and C yield slightly higher benefits than the proposed scenario H that was selected based on the institutional capacity of MPW. We can also observe the more drastic economic consequences of reducing the average agency expenditures to levels below US$30.0 million/year (Scenarios F, G). Figure 2 shows the resulting network level of service for each budget scenario. The graph shows the average network roughness over the analysis period (20 years) for each budget scenario. We can see that for the proposed budget scenario H, the overall nctwork roughness over the next 20 years will be around 4.0 IRI. For scenarios D to G, reducing th agency expenditures will increase the network roughness and the resulting vehicle operating costs, yielding lower total costs to society than scenario H.
 Annex 7 Page 5 of 13 14. Figure 3 presents the evolution of the network condition over the next six years under the proposed budget scenario H. This graph shows the percentage of the network length in Good, Fair and Poor/Critical condition. The first year (1995) represents the current network condition and the following years show the expected improvements due to implementation of the proposed program. The percent of the network in Good condition (roughness < 4.0 IRI) will increase from around 13 percent to 87 percent over the five years. Figure 4 shows the expected network utilization over the next five years for the proposed scenario. The graph presents the total network utilization, in million vehicle-kilometers per year, and the percent of the vehicles driving on Good, Fair and Poor/Critical roads, and shows that in year 2001 the great majority of users will be serviced by good roads. Projected Work Program Requirements 15. Figure 5 presents the yearly financial periodic expenditures required to implement the proposed scenario H, by operation type. For this scenario, the yearly recurrent expenditures required, for patching and routine maintenance, are about US$4.4 million per year. We can see that in the first two years the resources will be used mostly on 10 to 12 cm overlays, the third and fourth years will be dedicated mostly to 6 to 8 cm overlays and reconstructions will mostly be done in year five. Figure 6 presents the work program in kilometers for the proposed scenario H by operation type. In the first two years around 300 kilometers per year will be worked on, in year three around 550 kilometers will be worked on, and in years four to six around 400 kilometers per year of works will be undertaken. 16. Figure 7 presents, for the proposed scenario H, the average periodic expenditures per km needed to implement the scenario for three, four-year periods starting in 1996. We can see that in the first four- year period (1996-99), the network needs yearly expenditures in the order of US$16,500 per km and after the backlog is eliminated the yearly requirements are reduced to around US$9,000 per km in the second four-year period, and US$4,500 per km in the third four-year period, i.e., the network is stabilized in about ten years. D. Evaluation of the Sections to be Financed by the Loan 17. The pilot program to be financed under the proposed loan was selected from the overall rehabilitation program, and the individual road sections included in this pilot program were subjected to specific economic evaluations. In selecting the pilot program components, economic merit was not the sole criterion since the pilot program's components were to be used as demonstration projects, to develop improved maintenance standards and project implementation procedures in each of the four regional directorates. Therefore the rates of return obtained on the pilot program do not correspond to the highest rates of return available within the overall program. Attachment 1 to Annex 2 presents the NPV for the first year of the pilot program components, and shows that each component has a positive NPV at a 12 percent (real) discount rate.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the National Roads Project are to: (1) implement a pilot road rehabilitation program in support of the Road Rehabilitation Program; (2) strengthen institutional capacity for maintenance and development of the national road network; and, (3) reduce reliance on the Government's budget by requiring users to pay for the provision of roads. The main components of the project are: (A) road rehabilitation works, a three year pilot program to rehabilitate about 400 km of selected international, primary, and secondary roads; (B) technical assistance to: (i) support the Ministry of Public Works' Program Implementation Unit in planning and programming works, preparing guidelines for and reviewing feasibility/environmental studies, undertaking all procurement actions necessary for the project, and monitoring outputs; (ii) carry out a detailed road user charges study to recommend the level and structure of tariffs; (iii) assist in the preparation of laws and regulations to implement the Statement of Road Sector Policy; and (iv) strengthen the capability of the Directorate of Roads to develop and implement the Road Rehabilitation Program, including preparation of feasibility / environmental studies and supervision of works; and (C) procurement of vehicles, computers, office equipment, road laboratory equipment, traffic counting equipment and axle-load control equipment for better management of roads.
